Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: Thanks FishyGuts - so do notary nodes have a btc wallet with funds and ability to send a transaction to the bitcoin network? where do they get the btc is it entrusted to them from the KMD ICO supply?

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: just trying to understand ways in which KMD is not as decentralized as it could be. or is each notary node responsible to get its own BTC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notary nodes are given the BTC needed to notarize from ICO funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and yes, the notaries use a sortition process to multisign a proposed notarization to the network. then nodes that already had the same block mark it as notarized, so all nodes validate the proposed notarizations. powers of notary nodes are much less than for other consensus systems

Author: LeshAft9#0083
Content: so would the person holding and disbursing the BTC for notarizing be a single point of failure? is there a plan to transition to a more decentralized way that is indefinitely sustainable?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the ICO funds are in a multisig

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: eventually the funds will run out, so it isnt indefinitely sustainable as it stands. we will need to build up a large enough set of notarized chains and charge a small amount to cover the BTC funds. we have 10 years to do this, i think at that point it will be quite decentralized as the different chains would each be responsible for a fraction of the total needed

Content: have the recent low btc fees helped makethe ICO funds last longer?

Author: Alexfrog#1338
Content: I would imagine that they wouldve run out fast in the late 2017 prices

Author: Justaguy#6181
Content: I'm messing around with my chain, and when I created it I didn't include -ac_public. Does this mean that the rpcuser and rpcpassword in the mychain.config file does nothing?

Author: Justaguy#6181
Content: like, if i wanna switch between wallets, what commands would do that? or furthermore, if i wanted to access my wallet on another computer?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Justaguy "No" and "only the computers with a given wallet.dat can see the addresses it contains". You can import the private key of any address to any number of nodes, and each node will be able to spend funds in it or "watch" it in read-only mode

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ac_public=1 means "no shielded transactions" and defaults to 0

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
`Does this mean that the rpcuser and rpcpassword in the mychain.config file does nothing?`
Those are the credential settings (user/password pair) to send commands to the daemon (needed for `if i wanted to access my wallet on another computer?`)

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
`if i wanna switch between wallets, what commands would do that?`
you'd add `-wallet=somenewwallet.dat` when you execute komodod

Author: Draeth#3300
Content: Hey all! With the Permission of jl777c, I am going to create a physical version of the Komodo coin, and I need the community's help in a few ways! First, I'd like to get some input on what you would like the coin to look like (gold, silver, with/without colors, etc). Second, i'll produce a preliminary design and you all can request changes to be made, etc. Once that's done, i'll send to the manufacturer to get digital proofs made and quotes. If everyone is good with how the digital proofs look, i'll start taking pre-orders (i need at least 20 to get the coin to be made, which will be posted on my website). If you want other changes after the digital proofs are in, i'll make them and send it back n repeat the process til everyone (or just about everyone) is satisfied. For reference, I made one for Piratechain, which is for sale on my website: https://physicalcryptocoins.com
